CONCLUSION: No violation of Art. 6-1 concerning the right to a fair hearing;No violation of Art. 6-1 concerning the right to an impartial tribunal
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant formed CARDINAL construction companies to build catering and accommodation facilities at the request of the Olympic Games Organisation Committee ( “ the ORG ” ) . He was the manager of the companies . He held PERCENT of the shares in CARDINAL of the companies , which was the sole shareholder in the other CARDINAL . He also acted as guarantor of virtually all the companies ' debts .

CARDINAL . As the works were not completed within the agreed period , the ORG suspended payment for them . On DATE the applicant lodged a declaration of insolvency on behalf of the companies with the registry of ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG made an order for the judicial reorganisation of the applicant 's CARDINAL companies . It named PERSON as the insolvency judge , and also appointed a deputy insolvency judge , a judicial administrator and a creditors ' representative . It ordered a DATE observation period during which the judicial administrator was to draw up a report on the companies ' finances and labour force with his recommendations as to whether the companies should continue or cease trading . The observation period was renewed twice .

CARDINAL . During the observation period , the insolvency judge made various orders , namely : orders for the appointment of an expert on management supervision ( DATE ) , a valuer ( DATE ) and an accountant ( CARDINAL DATE ) ; orders declaring claims time - barred ( CARDINAL orders were made on CARDINAL DATE and others on DATE , CARDINAL DATE , CARDINAL and DATE , CARDINAL DATE , DATE and CARDINAL DATE ) ; orders for the restitution of equipment ( on DATE , DATE and DATE ) ; an order authorising the applicant 's intervention in the management of the hotels ( on DATE ) ; an order dismissing applications for the restitution of equipment ( DATE ) ; orders for an action to be brought against CARDINAL of the other contracting parties and for other measures ( on DATE ) and for the restitution of equipment ( DATE ) ; orders dismissing CARDINAL members of staff ( DATE ) and a further member of staff ( DATE ) ; and lastly an order for the freezing of accounts ( DATE ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE the judicial administrator asked ORG to decide whether to accept the applicant 's proposals for its recovery through continued trade .

CARDINAL . The applicant appeared at the hearing and gave evidence as the manager of the companies concerned . The judicial administrator and the creditors ' representative also made oral submissions . The judicial administrator presented a report in which he explained to ORG the history of the dealings which had led to the applicant 's filing in insolvency . He then related to the court events during the observation period . He stressed that the applicant 's recovery plan had been accepted by a majority of the creditors . He raised doubts over certain issues and said that it was for the applicant to dispel those doubts by putting up financial and professional guarantees .

CARDINAL . ORG decided ( on application by ORG ) that before approving the applicant 's proposed recovery plan , it needed to be satisfied that the companies ' continued economic activity would be permanent . For that purpose , it needed financial and professional guarantees from the applicant . It therefore asked him to produce certain additional documents so that it could be sure that the guarantees existed . The applicant lodged an additional file in response to that request . In the light of the new file lodged by the applicant , the administrator filed a supplemental report .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG terminated the observation period and put the CARDINAL companies into compulsory liquidation . It held that the proposed recovery plan was not accompanied by sufficiently reliable guarantees to ensure that the companies could continue as a going concern . The judgment contained , inter alia , the following passages :
“ Consequently the ORG must find that the proposed plan is not accompanied by the guarantees required to ensure its future economic activity in a difficult sector .

Pursuant to the provisions of sections CARDINAL , CARDINAL and CARDINAL of Law no . CARDINAL of DATE , it therefore orders the compulsory liquidation of the aforementioned companies in accordance with the provisions of LAW of that statute and holds as follows .
FOR THESE REASONS
The ORG , sitting in public and as a court of first instance ,
Having examined the insolvency judge 's report ,
Having examined the judicial administrator 's report ...
Terminates the observation period ... ”

CARDINAL . ORG reassigned the case to the insolvency judge , decreed that the administrator 's mission had been completed and appointed the creditors ' representative as liquidator of the companies . The insolvency judge sat on the bench that delivered that judgment in his capacity as President of the ORG . He was assisted by the Vice - President of ORG and another judge .

CARDINAL . In a judgment of DATE , ORG upheld ORG judgment in its entirety . It delivered its decision after examining the applicant 's recovery plan , the judicial administrator 's report and the liquidator 's submissions . The applicant attended the hearing and made oral observations .

On DATE the applicant appealed to ORG . He put forward CARDINAL grounds of appeal based on LAW . On DATE ORG dismissed the appeal . The applicant had argued that ORG had not been impartial because the insolvency judge had sat on the bench of ORG that had ordered the companies ' liquidation after playing an active role in the period of observation of the companies . ORG met the argument as follows :

“ ... the fact that , in accordance with LAW of DATE , the insolvency judge sat on the bench that made the order for compulsory liquidation is not contrary to the provisions of LAW of LAW ; that ground of appeal is unfounded ; ... ”
The applicant 's second ground of appeal read as follows :

“ ... the insolvency judge 's report and accompanying documents were not communicated to the appellants . In that regard the hearing was not fair for the purposes of LAW and the rights of the defence were not respected within the meaning of LAW . A hearing can only be said to be fair – again for the purposes of LAW if equality of arms is ensured , in other words , if each party is aware of all the matters on which the court will rely in coming to its decision . Among those matters , the insolvency judge 's report plays a paramount role in helping the court to reach its decision . However , it is deemed privileged information to which the debtor is unable to have access ( it is not communicated , does not appear in the official case file which may be communicated and is not read out at the hearing ) . Nor , consequently , may he contest it . The principle of a fair hearing is thus infringed for the purposes of the LAW and the rights of the defence under LAW denied .
ORG answered that argument as follows :

“ ... LAW DATE provides that the insolvency judge 's report may be presented orally ; that provision is not contrary to LAW . Accordingly , since the applicant has not submitted that the insolvency judge did not present his report orally , this ground of appeal can not succeed ... ”

The applicant also raised a ground of appeal based on the fact that ORG had failed either to summons the other party to a contract to appear or to take evidence from it . ORG dismissed that ground of appeal , holding :

“ ... other contracting parties are only required to be summonsed to appear before the court of appeal when assignment of the contract as part of a plan for the sale of the undertaking is envisaged . There is no provision requiring other contracting parties to be summonsed to appear when an order for compulsory liquidation is made . This ground of appeal is therefore unfounded ... ”

Concurrently , on DATE the applicant lodged an application with the President of ORG for an order for the communication of the insolvency judge 's report . On DATE the President of ORG dismissed the application , holding :
“ ... the insolvency judge 's report is clothed in the secrecy of the deliberations and can not be communicated to anyone . ”

Section DATE “ This Act institutes a new procedure of judicial reorganisation proceedings with the aim of preserving undertakings , maintaining their activities and employment and clearing their debts . ”

Judicial reorganisation shall take place in accordance with a plan approved in a judicial decision at the end of an observation period . The plan shall provide for the continuation or the sale of the activity of the undertaking . When neither alternative appears possible , the undertaking shall be put into compulsory liquidation . ”

Section DATE “ When an order for judicial reorganisation is made an observation period shall commence so that a report can be prepared on the company 's finances and labour force and proposals made for the continuation or sale of the undertaking . If neither alternative appears possible , the court shall make an order for compulsory liquidation . ”

Section DATE “ In the insolvency order the court shall designate the insolvency judge [ from a list compiled by the president of judges with DATE experience ] and CARDINAL court officers , namely the administrator and the creditors ' representative . It shall invite the works council or , if none , the staff delegates or , if none , the members of staff to appoint a staff representative from the undertaking ... ”

Section CARDINAL is contained in the part of the LAW relating to the pursuit of the undertaking 's activity . The LAW provides that the activity of the undertaking shall continue during the observation period subject to the provisions of Section CARDINAL , which reads as follows :

“ At any stage , the court may , at the request of the administrator , the creditor 's representative , the debtor , ORG or on its own initiative and in the light of the insolvency judge 's report , order the cessation of all or part of the activity or compulsory liquidation . ”

The court shall deliver its judgment in private after hearing the debtor , the administrator , the creditors ' representative and the representatives of the works council or , if none , the staff delegates or after duly summonsing them to appear . ”
ORG said :

“ The insolvency judge has the role of supervising the administration and compulsory liquidation while also exercising an investigative role ; his presence in the trial ORG is an exception to the principle that the investigation and trial stages should be kept separate . ”

The facts , however , were concerned with another aspect of the procedure , namely the making of a personal bankruptcy order against the manager of a company that had been put into liquidation . The same judge had sat as president and insolvency judge in CARDINAL sets of proceedings in which first the company 's judicial reorganisation and then its compulsory liquidation had been ordered . He had subsequently served a summons on the manager of the company to appear before the commercial court ( the summons contained a recommendation that the manager should be declared personally bankrupt ) and presided over that court , which made an order declaring the manager personally bankrupt . ORG quashed the judgment of the commercial court on the ground that there had been a violation of LAW . It found that the fact that the insolvency judge had sat on the bench that heard the case was inconsistent with the principle that the investigation and trial stages should be kept separate and could legitimise the appellant 's concerns regarding the objective impartiality of the court that had delivered the impugned decision ( PERSON DATE , jurisprudence , pp . CARDINAL et seq . ) . ORG relied essentially on the role of appearances and expressly followed the judgments in GPE v. GPE of DATE , Series A no . CARDINAL , p. CARDINAL , § DATE , and PERSON v. GPE of DATE , Series A no . CARDINAL , p. CARDINAL , § CARDINAL .
